I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Strategy 2030, the long-term corporate strategy of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
recognizes the distinct development challenges of small island developing states (SIDS) and 
fragile  and  conflict-affected  situations  (FCAS),  and  promotes  a  differentiated  approach  to 
operations in these groups of developing member countries (DMCs).1 In line with Strategy 2030, 
the technical assistance (TA) will support the integration of a differentiated approach to ADB’s 
operations in the urban sector across the Pacific region. The TA will focus on strengthening the 
resilience of urban areas in Pacific SIDS and FCAS by addressing the root causes of their 
vulnerability and fragility, including low institutional capacities for planning and managing urban 
development. The TA will help SIDS and FCAS adopt a longer-term horizon for planning, and 
support  governments  to  prepare  a  more  programmatic  and  multisector  approach  to  urban 
infrastructure investments in 34 countries.2 Particular attention will be given to institutional 
strengthening and capacity development with emphasis on learning by doing. The TA will also 
help strengthen regional coordination and integration by supporting regional studies, reinforcing 
existing networks, and establishing new ones. This will bolster earlier proactive collaboration in 
project development, help ADB tailor its approaches and processes to the needs and constraints 
of SIDS and FCAS, and enable stronger resilience and sustainability of urban centers in the 
Pacific. 
 
2.  On 19 November 2018, ADB approved the concept paper for this TA, with a budget of 
$3,000,000 from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).3 The TA is in 
line with the implementation priorities of the Pacific Approach, 20162020 and is included in the 
regional operations business plan, 20192021 for the Pacific.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Pacific SIDS and FCAS face daunting obstacles to development—isolation from markets, 
geographic dispersion, small populations, constrained natural resources, and the high risk of 
disaster triggered by natural hazards. Strategy 2030 sets the course to respond effectively to the 
changing development needs and challenges in Asia and the Pacific. Under it, ADB will sustain 
its efforts to eradicate extreme poverty and expand its vision to achieve a prosperous, inclusive, 
resilient, and sustainable Asia and the Pacific. The strategy recognizes the distinct development 
challenges of SIDS and FCAS and outlines ADB’s differentiated approach to these DMCs. 
Strategy 2030 contains commitments to providing long-term financing and capacity development 
assistance to help build resilience and address causes of vulnerability. ADB support prioritizes 
institutional development and governance reforms, essential infrastructure and social services, 
targeted social assistance, climate change adaptation, environmental sustainability, and disaster 
risk management.  
 
4.  Development experience elsewhere has shown that urban centers can be the drivers of 
economic growth—through trade links, growth of the private sector, job creation, and social 
service  provision.  However,  this  has  not  been  the  case  in  the  Pacific,  where,  although

Alliance of Small Island States. Therefore, all 14 Pacific ADB DMCs are classified as SIDS.

2 
 
urbanization is happening at a fast rate, strong economic growth did not follow. In 2017, 7 out of 
14 Pacific DMCs had the majority of their populations residing in urban areas. The United Nations 
projected that the number of people living in urban areas in the 14 DMCs will increase from 
2.4 million in 2017 to 3.4 million in 2030, to 6.0 million by 2050.5 Yet, of the 2.4 million residing in 
urban areas in 2017, more than 1 million lived in informal settlements, often without basic services 
such as potable water or sanitation and with limited access to economic opportunities.6 The 
inability of states to match service provision with growing urban populations is also a major 
challenge to internal resilience. With urban populations growing faster than national populations 
and youth unemployment being a major problem in most Pacific cities, the potential for urban 
unrest and conflict is considerable.7 The civil conflict in Solomon Islands from 1998 to 2003 had 
its origins in the ruralurban migration and unresolved land ownership issues. Tonga experienced 
rioting in its capital in 2006, while Port Moresby is afflicted by an increase in violent crimes. 
 
5.  Poorly planned and managed urban centers constrain growth, prevent the achievement 
of the Sustainable Development Goals, and contribute to the fragility of Pacific nations caused by 
a myriad problems—trade and transport congestion, unreliable energy supply, lack of formal 
sector job growth, limited access to housing, inadequate basic urban infrastructure services, poor 
quality of social services, and red tape constraining business growth. The lack of consultative 
long-term planning; insufficient capacity to prepare, finance, manage, and coordinate urban 
investments; and an ad hoc approach to the development of infrastructure are undermining urban 
development in the Pacific. These factors are a major constraint to achieving Strategy 2030’s 
operational priority of more livable cities. The ad hoc approach to urban development further 
increases the vulnerability of urban communities to climate change, disaster triggered by natural 
hazards, and economic shocks. 
 
6.  ADB has been scaling up its assistance to SIDS and FCAS in the Pacific, working with the 
public and private sectors to enable sustainable and resilient urban designs, climate-proof 
infrastructure, improve power supply, and build efficient and safe transport networks. However, 
project success rates in the Pacific remain considerably lower than for ADB overall—53% of 
completed projects in the Pacific were rated successful in 20142017, compared with 75% of all 
ADB sovereign projects in the same period.8 Ensuring that the outputs and outcomes of ADB-
financed Pacific operations are sustainable remains a critical challenge, since only 45% of 
completed projects were rated likely sustainable in 20142017. Lessons from the completed 
operations point to the need to ensure a more strategic approach to project selection and planning, 
strengthen the capacity of planning and implementing agencies, improve the procurement and 
design readiness of operations, resolve land ownership issues in advance of project approval, 
and ensure sufficient attention to post-completion operation and maintenance. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: resilience, productivity, and sustainability of 
urban centers in the Pacific strengthened.9 The TA will have the following outcome: capacity of

B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Long-term urban development strategies and capital investment plans for 
priority urban infrastructure and services formulated. The TA will support the preparation of 
urban development strategies in 34 Pacific DMCs. These strategies will take a long-term and 
highly cross-sector-oriented, consultative approach to the development of urban areas and 
identify investment needs for urban services such as water supply, sanitation, flood control, solid 
waste management, urban transport, energy, health, and education. The strategies will be based 
on comprehensive assessments and will tackle the root causes of vulnerability and fragility of 
urban settlements in the Pacific, including their vulnerability to climate change, disaster triggered 
by natural hazards, and economic shocks. They will build on the lessons and outputs of other TAs 
related to urban development in the Pacific and will consider opportunities for mainstreaming 
gender  and  Sustainable  Development  Goals.11 The  strategies  will  be  used  to  support  the 
development of integrated capital investment plans that identify high-priority projects over the 
medium term in the urban areas in pilot DMCs.12 The investment plans will identify possible 
sources of financing, including cofinancing from development partners and the private sector. 
Efforts will focus on defining the most suitable modalities for assistance, such as programmatic 
or stand-alone approaches and appropriate financing instruments. To provide foundations for the 
implementation of capital plans, the TA will also support the establishment of project readiness 
financing facilities in the pilot DMCs, building on the lessons from the Pacific Project Improvement 
Action Plan.13 The financial facilities will support feasibility studies for priority projects including 
comprehensive  disaster  risk  and  climate  assessments,  due  diligence  with  social  and 
environmental risks assessments, and preliminary and detailed engineering designs; and will help 
formulate a pipeline of projects that are procurement-ready.  
 
9.  Output 2: Capacity development and institutional strengthening for urban planning 
and project development delivered. The TA will provide capacity development and institutional 
strengthening to government counterparts responsible for urban planning and management in the 
areas  of  project  identification,  preparation,  financing,  implementation,  and  operation  and 
maintenance; and to local contractors on ADB’s procurement guidelines and procedures. A heavy 
emphasis will be placed on learning by doing. The TA will support business process reforms that 
are  tailored  to  the  needs  and  nature  of  ADB’s  operation  in  the  Pacific  and  facilitate  the 
establishment of national (i.e., country-based) registries of consultants (firms and individuals), 
contractors, suppliers, and service providers working on ADB-financed operations. The registries 
will be useful in building up a contracting service industry, with a focus on promoting businesses 
headed by women.14  Institutional strengthening and capacity development programs will be 
based on needs assessments to address chronic capacity gaps in the Pacific, and to facilitate the

of reaching out to more participants, ADB will update and develop online learning courses that 
cater to different knowledge levels and provide on-demand learning opportunities. These efforts 
will enable a more proactive collaboration in the early stage of project development and help ADB 
tailor approaches and processes to the needs and constraints of Pacific DMCs.  
 
10.  Output  3:  Regional  networks  established  and  knowledge  products  to  support 
sustainable urban development produced. The TA will help find regional solutions to some 
typical urban development challenges in the Pacific, such as small economies, remoteness, 
limited institutional capacity, and vulnerability to climate change and economic, environmental, 
and disaster-related shocks. The TA will support regional studies on urgent issues related to 
urban development, such as the feasibility of developing a regional response to solid waste 
management in the Pacific. It will also help strengthen regional networks such as the Pacific Water 
and Wastewater Association and, as needed, establish new networks (by promoting sustainably 
inclusive membership), such as among seaport or airport operators. This will facilitate cooperation 
between developing countries and permit effective exchange of experiences and knowledge in 
these areas. The TA will also support pertinent regional events and provide trainers and resource 
persons to facilitate the work of the regional networks.  Opportunities to collaborate with regional 
institutions will be sought.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $3,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. The TA will cover the travel costs of ADB staff acting as resource persons for 
seminars and workshops. The TA budget may be increased during implementation subject to the 
demand for the TA activities. 
 
12.  The governments of participating DMCs will provide counterpart support in the form of 
country data, counterpart staffing (if needed), office space for consultants, and other in-kind 
contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency,  and  its  Pacific  Department  will  administer  and 
implement the TA. The implementation will take 60 months, from 1 January 2019 to 31 December 
2023.  
 
14.  The TA will disseminate knowledge through various platforms. It will input planned TA 
outputs  to  k-Nexus  to  build  on  ADB’s  accumulated  knowledge  and  experience,  minimize 
duplication, and facilitate dissemination.15 To ensure continuous learning on urban planning and 
project  development,  e-learning  courses  will  be  developed  to  provide  on-demand  learning 
opportunities. These courses may be hosted on existing ADB platforms for online learning to 
ensure that they remain accessible beyond TA closure. In collaboration with ADB’s Department 
of Communications, the assessments of urban settlements, urban development strategies, and 
investment  plans  will  be  disseminated  through  various  channels,  depending  on  the  target 
audience. All outputs will be made freely available to the public through ADB's corporate website. 
Limited copies will be produced for general dissemination and conduct targeted workshops in 
headquarters, representative offices, and resident missions. 
 
                                                
15 ADB. 2018. k-Nexus (accessed 15 November 2018).

individual  consultants  and  an  international  firm  are  in  Appendix  3.16 ADB  will  engage  the 
consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its

final reports to ADB. ADB’s findings of assessments will be the basis for evaluating the consultants’ 
performance.  
 
17.  Social media and websites. To ensure accessibility of the learning courses beyond the 
TA completion date, ADB’s Pacific Department will explore hosting the proposed e-learning 
courses within the learning management system maintained by the Knowledge Advisory Services 
Center under ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department. ADB makes 
learning courses on select development topics available to external participants on its k-Learn 
and Development Asia websites. The site provides online courses on various sector and thematic 
areas as part of ADB’s work to share knowledge in the region. ADB’s Pacific Department will work 
with the Knowledge Advisory Services Center’s team of e-learning specialists to update and 
manage the content of the courses. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Implementing a Differentiated Approach to Urban Development in the Pacific, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.
